body.p:
The commencement of the College
recess gives me leisure to attend some what to
correspondence too much neglected. I have a
very respectable pile of letters before me of rather
antique date which testify and declare that I have
either been lazy these last few months, or my time
has been much occupied. I rather incline to the
latter supposition and I hope you will also—at
least I have had the wish to write you ere this.
With the resolution of years I find I have new
duties and new claims on my time. My Hebrew
must be examined occasionally to see how he
“gets on” at school where he learns English
grammar, arithmetic, French &c and as I am
his Hebrew pedagogue at home, the young
gentleman (now ? in his ninth year),
takes up a little of my time. The application
of this long interesting Hebrew I leave to yourself.
I have commenced, but not finished the Biography
of my late revered father Hebrew to which you

refer in your last. I have before written you that
I was asked for it elsewhere; though I should
be very pleased to see it in the Occident, and
shall certainly send you a copy duly authenticated
as you request. You are not, you write, a close
reader of the Jewish publications—neither am I.
I give you, as you requested me, credit for
Mr J. H. J's $3— Please inform me how our
account stands. I regret to say I am not quite
sure as to the Calendars I sent you. Besides
the dozen sent you per Miss S. J. (21 May '61)
you had “ I reckon” another dozen. Please
let me know how the matter really is, as
though I made an entry some where, I cannot
remember where just now.

As items of news (if such indeed
they be to you) I might mention that our
synagogue was reopened for the late holy days
after having been thoroughly renovated
internally. The cong. have been much
indebted to the pious zeal of Mrs Henry Benjamin

and Miss Sarah Joseph for the re-adornment
of their synagogue. Mrs. J. H. Joseph contributed
a very elegant Sepher Mantle and even the
? made a subscription among themselves
started by Miss D. Benjamin
and procured for the occasion a very handsome
cover for the readers desk and cloak for
one of the Sepharim. And those sums another time.

The troubles in your distracted
country have caused Poznanski of Charleston
and his family to remain here for the last
eight months. He is not the terrible fellow
I took him for; and I fancy Messrs Lilienthal
Einhorn Adler and one or two more are,
more mischievous than he was or ever will
be. Dr. Mayer of Albany has been in here
once or twice—his wife who was arrested
in Burlington by the U. S. authorities is staying
here for a couple of months. I see no prospect
of a speedy reconstruction of the Union on
the old basis. I have no knowledge of the
south much, but I should scarcely think
they will allow themselves to be whipt

back, et afres?? our turn will come I presume
and we shall have northern invincibles
occupying Montreal n'est ce pas?

When we meet we can discuss
these weighty matters. Till then things, I presume
will go their way uninfluenced by what we
may say, so why vex ourselves therewith?

During my recent visit to England
I found that it was rather more common than I
expected, to exchange publications. So if every you
want a few English's, Calendars, &c on these terms (with
the usual discount, I shall be glad to supply you,
As I am sending on a parcel to Miss Gratz, I will
enclose you a few numbers of Part 1 of Sanatary?
Institutions, recently put in paper covers which you
perhaps could circulate without much trouble
among your friends Jewish or Christian—selling
price 25 cents a copy, with 20% off commission.

I have now pretty well covered my
paper, and must therefore bid you adieu for the
present. Mrs De Sola and family untie
in kind regards and with best wishes

May I trouble you to send up to
Miss Gratz the copy
